Award.AwardTitle: BII-Design: Integrating Biological Resilience Across Scales
Award.AbstractNarration: The concept of resilience - the ability of any system to return to a previous state after a perturbation â€“ provides an ideal opportunity to unite different scales of biological research. The ever-increasing specialization of scientific research has made it challenging for researchers in different fields of biology to exchange ideas. The study of system resilience, however, is common to all biological fields of study. The overarching objective of this project is to use the theme of resilience to bridge cellular, organismal, and community-level scales of biology by synthesizing the tools, concepts, and approaches used by the different research fields. They will be integrated through 1) collaborative research that includes undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, and faculty, 2) curricular enrichment, and 3) outreach to other institutions, non-profits, and industry. Conserved mechanisms of resilience identified through these activities will be applicable to engineer and manage biological systems in medical, agricultural, industrial, and natural contexts.<br/><br/>This project will challenge scientists to span disciplinary, taxonomic, methodological, and other divides in biology to build and apply a unified framework for biological resilience. Many fields of biology have described resilience in their systems of study, but rarely are there integrative efforts to search for common patterns and processes of resilience across temporal and spatial scales. The first step of the project is to examine how existing models and metrics of resilience are implemented across biological scales. The second step is to determine if there are common mechanisms across scales that allow biological systems to maintain resilience. The final step will be to identify how the basic science of biological resilience can be used to design and manage cellular, organismal, and ecological systems. These areas of resilience will be examined through interdepartmental seminars in biological resilience, a regional symposium on biological resilience, a new graduate module on biological resilience, and graduate research fellowships in biological resilience. The investigators will carefully examine and refine the existing lexicon for biological resilience that can be widely adopted by other biologists and integrative biology research institutions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the grand challenges in the biological sciences is integrating knowledge from different levels of biological organization to solve global challenges, from cancer to climate change. Finding common themes, patterns, approaches, and metrics across many different areas of biological research can help unify biology to solve these challenges. Resilience – the capacity of a system to recover from a perturbation – is pervasive in living systems and has been proposed as a unifying concept that can integrate biology. The overall objective of our Biological Resilience Integration Institute at Tufts University was to explore how biological resilience could unite disparate fields of biology. We did this through interdepartmental seminars, a regional symposium, a new graduate seminar course, and graduate research fellowships.

In our interdisciplinary seminar series, we invited speakers from a range of disciplines (from engineering to philosophy) to explain their perspectives on resilience. Speakers from both outside and within Tufts covered historical and contemporary visions of resilience in computer science, engineering, philosophy, ecology, molecular biology, conservation biology, and other fields. Discussions after these seminars helped facilitate cross-system thinking and further exploration of how metrics, mechanisms, and applications of resilience are used across biology and in related fields.

A one-day symposium was another catalyst for exploring common patterns and processes of biological resilience across disciplines. In the first half of the symposium, various working groups with representatives from different areas of biology explored several resilience themes including resilience trade-offs across scales of biological systems, redundancy as a mechanism of resilience, and how resilience can be a unifying theme across undergraduate biology curricula. Themes that emerged from this workshop session are part of a review paper written by the group. The second half of the symposium was open to the public and had faculty and graduate students from Tufts discuss how their research relates to biological resilience and how thinking about resilience changed how they thought about their own research fields. To end this exciting day of ideation and discussions, we had a keynote address about how network analyses can be used to understand resilience in biological systems.

Graduate research support (fellowships and funding for materials) and a graduate seminar course provided training opportunities for PhD students in our department. Eight graduate students developed research proposals that spanned multiple areas of biology and students were provided with one semester of research support to complete this biological resilience research. At least five papers have resulted from these projects. A graduate seminar that ran for two years used weekly readings in resilience and guest lectures from faculty to facilitate discussions on how biological resilience operates across diverse systems, from cells to ecosystems.
